destination.label: Mauritius
destination.title: Mauritius: Much More than a Postcard

content.intro:
Almost everything has already been said about Mauritius, but what has been said is both enticing and true: endless beaches, a lagoon with an ideal temperature, lush vegetation clinging to the shores of the Indian Ocean, sublime golf courses, hotels that are more glamorous the one than the other, and the smiles of the Mauritians, a beautiful and friendly people.

Before understanding Mauritius, we have to delve a little into the outline of its history. This small English- and French-speaking island in the Indian Ocean, which has been independent since 1968, has a diverse cultural background, which includes Portuguese, Dutch, French, and English influences. This historical mix has shaped its identity and unique cultural richness.

Discover the enchanted wilderness and tranquillity of the south of the island, its coves, deserted beaches, and marine cemeteries, while skilled fingers strike the ravane, a large flat drum and the main instrument of Sega, the traditional music of African slaves. A little further west, the majestic Morne Mountain watches over chic hotels that nestle along the peninsula. The decor seems straight out of a painting with a deep blue sea, dazzling white beaches, and dark-green coconuts.

Taking the road north, we suggest a colourful and lively stopover in Mahébourg, where street vendors set up their wares on Mondays. Sugarcane fields and tea plantations stretch in all directions, and the sublime scents of frangipani, hibiscus, and anthuriums are all around the many Indian temples. With barely time to recover from these heady adventures, the Grand Bay and its harbour appear. From there it is on to Port Louis, the capital, with its waterfront shops and animated market, which offers myriad exotic fragrances, enlivening all the senses.

There is no need for equivocation: Mauritius will conquer you.

content.title: Foot soaks at the Seapoint Boutique Hotel

introduction.small: A heavenly setting for an idyllic moment, a unique scene to recharge your batteries. Facing the beach, discover the Seapoint Boutique Hotel, true haven of peace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Foot soaks at the Seapoint Boutique Hotel

paragraphs.text:
“There, all is just order and beauty, luxury, calm, and sensuality”, as Baudelaire eloquently wrote: a perfect description of the exotic and relaxing charms of the Seapoint Boutique Hotel. Located on the tip of the Pointe aux Canonniers, the establishment enjoys an exceptionally romantic setting, across the lagoon and the Northern islands. The bedrooms, suites and villa all offer a magnificent view of the infinity pool, by which you will love to rest, but most importantly of the ocean and long, fine sandy beaches. Modern and intimate, the decor draws its inspiration from a Mauritian village and is perfectly integrated into the environment, as it uses driftwood, pebbles, white walls with shades of blue and turquoise, as well as thatched roofs.
The hotel does not accommodate children under 12, attracting an “adult only” customer base of couples seeking a romantic getaway or parents looking for some peace. The restaurant and beach bar keep this perfection intact, mirrored by the beauty of the dinner set and the flavours of the meals. Enjoy the experience while contemplating the ocean, as your feet draw circles in the sand.

Seapoint Boutique Hotel
Coastal Road
Pointe aux Canonniers
Mauritius

+230 209 1055

www.seapointboutiquehotel.com

Rooms: from 269 MUR

content.title: Private villa for a high-end stay at Maradiva

introduction.small: Discover Mauritius under the best possible light at Maradiva, among the most beautiful hotels of the Indian Ocean. The promise of a magical stay, alone, with your family or your loved one.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Private villa for a high-end stay at Maradiva

paragraphs.text:
Along the vast Flic-en-Flac beach on Mauritius' west coast, the Maradiva hotel is hiding amid lush gardens. Divided into 65 roomy villas, inspired by Indian ashrams, the hotel guarantees you calm and intimacy. Every lodge gives onto Tamarin Bay and enjoys a private swimming pool in line with the terrace, as well as tailored services including a butler available upon request. Indian culture is given pride of place, with refined decoration, ayurvedic medicine and yoga classes. Take a break and jump in the ocean, which you will be able to gaze at from your bedroom. For an even more romantic getaway, ask for dinner to be served in a tent or directly on the beach. Let your toes brush against the sand and marvel at the wonder of the island's most blazing sunset.

Maradiva Villas Resort & Spas

content.title: Le Jardin de Pamplemousses, a universe of scents and colours

introduction.small: With its thousand and one plants from the four corners of the world, Le Jardin de Pamplemousses transports you to the Amazon, Africa and Asia.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Jardin de Pamplemousses, a universe of scents and colours

paragraphs.text:
Le Jardin de Pamplemousses, in the north of Mauritius, is one of the oldest botanic gardens in the southern hemisphere. On an area of 33 hectares, flowers, trees, spices and other plants flourish along innumerable paths, which bear the names of the women and men who contributed to the development of the park.

Created in 1770 by Pierre Poivre, Le Jardin de Pamplemousses has today adopted the name of Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam, the first prime minister who led the island to independence.

During your walk, you will be overwhelmed by the colours and scents of the garden. As you roam down the paths, admire trees from around the world: Chinese camphor trees, lychees, guava and flamboyants. Aquatic plants -water lilies, lotuses and water lilies -are near spices such as nutmeg or cinnamon. The garden has an impressive number of palm trees, 95 different species, including the talipot palm, which dies after its first and only bloom.

Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam Botanical garden
SSR Botanic Garden

Pamplemousses

+230 243 9401

www.ssrbg.govmu.org

content.title: La Maison d'Été: a chic refuge on the lagoon

introduction.small: Between wild creeks and lush nature, the Summer House opens its doors for an exclusive stay where elegance, gastronomy and getaway are the key words.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Maison d'Été: a chic refuge on the lagoon

paragraphs.text:
This is a secret address that feels like a family home, without pretension, without adornment. A eulogy to simplicity and understated luxury that are dear to Brigitte Baranes, the owner, who settled here four years ago. She welcomes you to the heart of her 'camp on the lagoon' that she decorated together with a Mauritian design firm.

The chosen atmosphere is halfway between design and Mauritian craftsmanship. This mixture of cultures is reflected in the 16 rooms of the establishment, with the turquoise waters of the lagoon and rolling waves in the background. In the kitchen, the same mix is seen in both restaurants: the chef concocts a cuisine with flavours of the world that has also made the reputation of La Maison d'Été. Right on the beach, you will be swept away by this place full of charm. And for a moment of well-being, let yourself relax into the hands of an expert for an enticing massage.

La Maison d'Été
Route côtière de Roches Noires

www.lamaisondete.com/?lang=en

Rooms: from 7,606 MUR

content.title: Revitalise yourself at the Oberoi Mauritius

introduction.small: Facing the Indian Ocean, the Oberoi Mauritius is the ideal place to take a break for yourself and reconnect with nature.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Revitalise yourself at the Oberoi Mauritius

paragraphs.text:
Just 9 miles north of Port Louis, in the natural marine park of the Bay of Turtles, the Oberoi Mauritius contemplates the ocean. On the white sandy beach that borders the hotel, palm trees seem to embrace the crystalline waters just a few metres away. Thanks to its spacious villas with large openings to the exterior and oak wood furniture, you will constantly feel in touch with nature.
Nestled behind lush greenery is the hotel spa. You can spend relaxing moments here and may not want to leave! The spa treatments combine modern and ancestral techniques to enhance the benefits of Ayurveda and Balinese rituals. You can also take part in yoga, tai chi or meditation classes, learn meditation techniques and even learn to sculpt. You will definitely leave for home with mind and body at peace.

The Oberoi Mauritius
Turtle Bay
Pointe aux Piments
Mauritius
+230 204 3600

www.oberoihotels.com

Rooms: from 26,523 MUR

content.title: Cocotiers Hotel, pretty as a postcard, and reasonably priced

introduction.small: With this small hotel, the dream of palms by the lagoon is within range of all pocketbooks.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cocotiers Hotel, pretty as a postcard, and reasonably priced

paragraphs.text:
With only 48 rooms, this small hotel in Baie-du-Tombeau, seven kilometres from the capital Port Louis, is one of the most affordable places in the island. The hotel overlooks a small beach where you'll feel immediately at ease, and though the pool isn't grandiose it's the perfect size for swimming lengths. The service and level of comfort are spot on. The rooms, in small bungalows around the pool and garden, are spacious (26 to 30 m2) and simply decorated. Each has a pretty view and an outdoor area - terraces for those on the ground floor and balconies for those on the first floor. Some can be converted into family rooms for up to two adults and three children.

Cocotiers Hotel

Baie du Tombeau
Mauritius

+230 206 8600

www.cocotiers-hotel-mauritius.com

Rooms: from 2,530 MUR

content.title: One & Only Le Saint Géran: paradise on earth

introduction.small: Elegant and refined style in idyllic, luxurious surroundings and a sensation of euphoria.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: One & Only Le Saint Géran: paradise on earth

paragraphs.text:
The One & Only Le Saint Géran is an iconic landmark in Mauritius, located on one of the most beautiful beaches of the island. Prestige meets peace and tranquillity with a sleek and regal style in a cosy, intimate atmosphere that redefines luxury. Opt for one of its 166 suites or a villa that combines sumptuous and harmonious decor and advanced technology with delicacy and chic.

All rooms of the hotel place you face to face with the magnificent panorama of the Indian Ocean or the tranquil nearby cove from the intimacy of your private terrace or balcony. A well-equipped spa and wellness centre are available for you to fully benefit from a moment of calm and serenity. Sports, like diving in the colourful seabed of the island, a round of golf, or a game of tennis, are also available. Fast muscle building, yoga, beach volleyball, and water skiing are also there to enrich your sport experience.

To complete this idyll, the hotel offers a range of culinary experiences to delight your taste buds in one of its four lavish restaurants.

One & Only Le Saint Géran

https://www.oneandonlyresorts.com/one-and-only-le-saint-geran-mauritius

content.title: The Governor invites you to his table on Ile Plate

introduction.small: In the 19th century it housed European travellers stricken with malaria. Today this small island, returned to its natural state, welcomes the lucky for an exceptional day.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Governor invites you to his table on Ile Plate

paragraphs.text:
A catamaran glides over the emerald waters of the Indian Ocean, where colourful fish thrive—direction, Plate Island. The skiff has soon beached to allow you to step onto the white sand.

The wilderness of the island, a true nature reserve, provides an immediate calming effect. You venture onto the sandy paths leading to the ruins of the governor's house, which today has metamorphosed into a restaurant, called quite simply, ‘Governor's House'. Reconstructed from lava stones from Mauritian volcanoes, the building displays an attractive contemporary style.

For lunch, the ‘governor' welcomes you. On the menu: grilled fish and seasonal salads. And to end the day away from the world, a cocktail facing the azure blue horizon.

Governor's House
Coastal Route
Pointe Malartic
Grand Bay

+230 263 5413

content.title: A hike on Le Morne and Pouce

introduction.small: Though hiking may not be the first activity that comes to mind when you think of Mauritius, it has several beautiful trails.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A hike on Le Morne and Pouce

paragraphs.text:
Lace up your hiking shoes to tackle majestic le Morne Mountain. Le Morne is a UNESCO World Heritage Site whose challenges will not disappoint experienced sportsmen. Climbing the first 255 metres is easy, but do not cry victory too soon as the trail suddenly becomes steeper, and reaching the cross erected at 500 metres above sea level requires some effort.

If you are with your family, you may find Pouce an easier approach. At 812 metres, the 360-degree view of the island is a delight for both young and old. Mauritius, as a volcanic island, offers a magical landscape with beaches and lagoons stretching across the horizon. Such a view is an exceptional reward for the hours of effort.

content.title: Mauritian atmosphere at Zilwa Attitude

introduction.small: At Zilwa Attitude Mauritian tradition is present in the tiniest grain of sand. The typical, authentic feel of the place offers a direct link to Mauritius' heart and soul.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mauritian atmosphere at Zilwa Attitude

paragraphs.text:
Inspired as much by traditional houses as Mauritian seaside settlements, the hotel is open to the trade winds, marine scents, and colours of the lagoon. Sip on a sweet exotic fruit drink on rattan armchairs and let yourself be swept away by the salty smell of sun-bleached driftwood.

Everything here anchors you in Mauritius, while the design touches blend perfectly with the Creole decor. On the horizon, the five northern islands float in the distance and a few metres from the shore, the private islands of Grand Zil and Ti Zilare often the stage for a convivial barbecue, or the intimacy of a massage. And everywhere you hear words spoken in Creole... Bienvéni!

Zilwa Attitude Hotel
Royal Road

content.title: Egrets Island and Blue Bay Marine Park

introduction.small: For a great escape to the heart of Mauritian fauna and flora, a boat trip to the nature reserve of Egrets Island and Blue Bay Marine Park is the thing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Egrets Island and Blue Bay Marine Park

paragraphs.text:
Egrets Island is natural poetry. On this small 25-hectare island, plants and animals—among the rarest of the island—live in perfect harmony.

Trees with strange names like beefwood, wooden pipe, rat wood, and palm bottle intertwine their roots. Indigenous birds, giant tortoises, and many other specimens are studied and protected. The Blue Bay Marine Park, among the most beautiful diving sites on the island, surrounds this magnificent coral stone.

Discover more than 50 varieties of live coral, and tropical fish by the thousands, either by glass-bottom boat, or with a mask and snorkel.

www.mauritian-wildlife.org

content.title: A sunset over Tamarin Bay

introduction.small: Far from the tourist bustle, Tamarin Bay is a peaceful, authentic setting, perfect for watching the radiant spectacle of the sunset.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A sunset over Tamarin Bay

paragraphs.text:
On the small beach of Tamarin, the tourists do not hurry by, but the Mauritians are used to gathering at the end of the day.

The village exudes tranquillity, barely disturbed by the cheerful notes of the small (and only) three-star hotel on the bay, run by Cyril Michel, a committed jazz man. Suddenly, the light dims. As in the theatre, it is a sign that the show is about to begin. For the star of the evening is slowly going to disappear. Its light, soft and orange, reflected on the sand and salt water, radiates across the horizon. In the distance, the mountains appear devoured by flames when, close to the other side of the river, the vegetation is like a sequined dress.

A pantheistic and dramatic ode that will leave you appeased and finally, wrapped in night.

Tamarin Bay
Mauritius

content.title: Three short rounds of kite surfing in One Eye Lagoon

introduction.small: Kite-surfing professionals are not mistaken. Today, Mauritius boasts an impressive range of kite-surfing spots, making the island one of the places to be.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Three short rounds of kite surfing in One Eye Lagoon

paragraphs.text:
At dawn, the sun gently adds her tanned tones to the turquoise waters of the Indian Ocean. The waves break, drawing a line of white foam on the horizon, and the winds begin to blow.

Here, at the foot of Le Morne Mountain, kite enthusiasts await this magic moment where One Eye, one of the fastest waves in the world, opens the show. From the beach, the show is equally impressive when the kites capture the trade winds and the boards take the rolling waves, causing surfers to fly into the air.

For some years now, flocks of dedicated surfers from all around the world have gathered in Mauritius, raising the island to the rank of essential kitesurfing spot.

www.yoaneye.com

http://mauritiusattractions.com/

content.title: A round of golf in an exceptional environment

introduction.small: Mauritius has recently become an important golf destination. With no less than eight 18-hole courses and three 9-hole layouts, professionals and amateurs come from afar to tread the soft greens.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A round of golf in an exceptional environment

paragraphs.text:
In Mauritius, fans of the little white ball have one foot on the green and the other in the lagoon. Whether a professional or golfing just for fun, what Mauritius offers includes an exceptional natural environment, the most up-to-date equipment, and ideal weather conditions throughout the year.

From the aptly named Paradis Golf Club, the only course on the island located within a resort, to the Heritage Golf Club, designed by the famous Peter Matkovich in the heart of sugarcane fields, there is something for everyone and for every level.

Reputedly, the most challenging is the Ile aux Cerfs (Deer Island) Golf Course, surrounded by the crystal-clear waters of the lagoon.

content.title: Chic ecology at Lakaz Chamarel

introduction.small: The luxury eco-lodge Lakaz Chamarel quickly engaged in the wave of intensive environmental protection to which the Mauritian government has committed, and is now the flagship address for Mauritian eco-tourism.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chic ecology at Lakaz Chamarel

paragraphs.text:
At the heart of the gorges of the Black River, Lakaz Chamarel could not have found a better location in which to flourish. Between lush vegetation and the view of the blue horizon, the eco-lodge blends beautifully into an environment conducive to wellbeing: bathed in the soft light of your private terrace, calm and serenity seem to keep you company.

The bright colours of the walls and materials function as allegories of happiness. At dusk, enjoy an outdoor tropical shower—and share a moment of intimacy with the stars.

content.title: The joyful church of Cap Malheureux

introduction.small: An ambiguous name – Cap Malheureux (Unhappy Cape), due to all the shipwrecks that have taken place on its shores – and a magnificent church with a red roof.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The joyful church of Cap Malheureux

paragraphs.text:
When the British landed and took possession of the island in 1810, Cap Malheureux saw a Protestant community settle on its land. Overlooking the turquoise bay, a red-roofed church, symbol of this village at the northern tip of the island, creates a striking contrast.

Even today, many faithful gather there on Sundays to attend services. Their songs and dances joyfully animate this picture-postcard site.

The sublime view on the Coin de Mire and the blue lagoon, the sandy beach and, further, a few fishermen and their colourful boats, is something to be savoured.

Cap Malheureux
Rivière du Rempart

content.title: An afternoon at the races

introduction.small: In Mauritius, horseracing is a national pastime. Spending an afternoon at the Champ de Mars racecourse places you in the heart of Mauritian culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: An afternoon at the races

paragraphs.text:
Squinting, fanning their faces with the racing programme, thousands of excited Mauritians gather in the stands of the Port Louis racetrack, which is the oldest in the Indian Ocean (it dates from 1812).

The horses take their places on the starting line, the atmosphere is tense, and everyone is holding their breath. That's racing! The clamour swells, covering the cries of street vendors and bookies. The Champ de Mars on the outskirts of Port Louis, below the Fort Adelaide Citadel, has become a real institution in the course of its 200-year history and horse racing has thus become a national recreation.

This is a must for anyone who wants to get as close as possible to Mauritian culture.

Champ de Mars
9, Dauphine Street
Port Louis

+230 212 2212

content.title: The Timeless Royal Palm

introduction.small: The Indian Ocean's number one palace is celebrating 30 years of quality. A member of Beachcomber Hotels, the Royal Palm is an address for those in the know.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Timeless Royal Palm

paragraphs.text:
‘Success is in the details' could be the motto of the Royal Palm Mauritius.

Just renovated, the delicate finishes to its decoration may seem tiny. But not for the initiated: with their insider look, they will appreciate the quality of the wood and the rare marbles of the unique furniture, the silky touch of precious fabrics, the special attention paid to the latest atmospheric touches.

The refinement of its style is matched only by the quality of its service—a thousand times recognised. At Royal Palm, asking is superfluous; your every wish is anticipated. Relax: there are 290 employees here for 69 suites, and they look after everything.

Royal Palm

www.royalpalm-hotels.com

content.title: Visiting the Domaine de l'Étoile, on horseback or quad

introduction.small: A full day of pleasure and natural riches awaits you at the largest private domain on the island, with indigenous forests, lush valleys, crystalline water, and great activities.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visiting the Domaine de l'Étoile, on horseback or quad

paragraphs.text:
Hats on, sunscreen, water bottle – all is ready for an adventurous day outdoors, on horseback at that. Once in the saddle, you may start off at a gentle trot while others gallop through the intensely coloured landscapes.

A rise may slow them down, but not for long as the valley offers an unlimited horizon that is far too tempting. For those who prefer motor transport, there are quad excursions on trails that are more or less steep, guaranteeing the promise of an unforgettable experience.

The adventure is not limited to daytime, so you may prolong your discoveries in the dark under a sparkling sky and perhaps catch a wild boar or deer in your headlights…

Domaine de l'Étoile
Sebastopol - B27
Mauritius

+230 729 1050

http://terrocean.mu/en/domaine-de-l-etoile/

content.title: Beachcomber Trou aux Biches: tropical elegance

introduction.small: At Trou aux Biches, peaceful greenery, legendary hospitality, and immutable charm reign, and time seems to have no sovereignty.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Beachcomber Trou aux Biches: tropical elegance

paragraphs.text:
With crystal-clear waters, a lush garden and sandy beach, the Trou aux Biches already has all the necessary assets for an inspiring stay. Add to that the requirements of privacy, space, and diversity on which the Trou aux Biches has focused and the result is an eco-conscious resort at the forefront of the latest luxury trends. The Clarins Spa, with its rustic cabins, offers wellbeing, while its idyllic setting, due largely to its legendary beach, provides privileged access to sumptuous sunsets.

For families, the hotel offers private villas masterfully scattered in the heart of tropical gardens like intimate oases for a memorable ‘home' away from home.

content.title: Swimming with dolphins

introduction.small: Well-travelled globetrotter or prudent tourist, no matter your status, swimming with dolphins remains a dream shared by all.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Swimming with dolphins

paragraphs.text:
Realising this fantasy in the Indian Ocean has its own particular flavour.

It is six in the morning. The sea, calm and serene, becomes iridescent with a thousand bluish splinters. It's time to meet the dolphins that swim in the turquoise waters of Mauritius lagoon. With a mixture of excitement and fear, you grab your mask and snorkel, aware of being only a dive away from this long-awaited experience.

As far as you can remember, you've always dreamed of swimming amongst dolphins. But living this fantasy here, in the middle of the Indian Ocean, takes a whole new meaning. Test the water? What's the point! Without a second thought, you take the plunge! Patience, as they start arriving in groups of 50-300, marine mammals – so curious and intelligent – to celebrate you. In the excitement, you lose your snorkel…

content.title: Creole dinner at the Ravanne

introduction.small: Set on Le Morne peninsula facing one of Mauritius' most beautiful beaches, Le Paradis welcomes gourmets to its opulent restaurant, La Ravanne.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Creole dinner at the Ravanne

paragraphs.text:
Facing one of the most beautiful beaches in Mauritius, the Paradis – quite probably the most full-blown resort in the Indian Ocean – welcomes delicate food lovers to try the heavenly setting of its La Ravanne restaurant. As the sun is setting, take your place aboard a large boat that will float you by sea directly to the foot of the Mauritian establishment.

The open-air setting is romantic and the cuisine, refined Creole. The russet colours of the end of the day upon the azure lagoon promise a soft and beautiful evening. The atmosphere is magical, peaceful, and the refined dishes wonderfully tasty, while conversations are barely troubled by the lapping of the water. Note that La Ravanne also boasts a bar where delicious local rum-based cocktails are being served.

Beachcomber Paradis Hotel
Le Morne
Mauritius

+230 601 9000

www.beachcomber-hotels.com/en/hotel/paradis-golf-resort-spa/dining

Menu: around 1,000 MUR

content.title: VIP Lunch at the Royal Palm Beach Bar

introduction.small: At the Beach Bar, the simplicity of the name is an illusion. Here, in the shade of a large almond tree, lunch is truly a moment of grace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: VIP Lunch at the Royal Palm Beach Bar

paragraphs.text:
The long branches of the almond tree seem to stretch effortlessly to protect you from the sun. Before you, the lagoon sparkles on the horizon.

At the helm of the kitchens is a talented and inventive French chef who in the space of 10 years, has become a true Mauritian. Michel de Matteis, Meilleur Ouvrier de France (MOF, or Best Craftman in his field) in 1991, former chef of the Dome of the Mirabeau Hotel in Monaco, has anchored himself in the heart of the Indian Ocean to reinterpret French cuisine with Mauritian colours and flavours. Thanks to local, fresh, and rigorously sourced ingredients, he offers spaghetti in bouillabaisse fish stock, a tuna, sesame and ginger tartare, prawns and wild lean fish, gently cooked on the grill. For dessert, end on a fresh note with vanilla-chocolate mini ice creams.

And if you want something else, ask for it. Whether you are a star or an ordinary person, there's no difference. At the Royal Palm, the service staff respond to all the client's whims and quirks.

Beach Bar - Royal Palm
Royal Road
Grand Bay

+230 209 8300

www.royalpalm-hotels.com

Menu: around 2,250 MUR

content.title: Beachcomber Dinarobin: glamour, calm and beauty

introduction.small: Dinarobin unveils its tropical elegance under the benevolent gaze of Le Morne Mountain, sharing the 7km beach, one of the most beautiful in Mauritius, with its neighbouring resort, Paradis.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Beachcomber Dinarobin: glamour, calm and beauty

paragraphs.text:
The Dinarobin is named after the first Arab traders from Oman, who sailed along the island's shores in the 10th century until the winds pushed their dhows to the coasts of Kerala or the Far East.

Serenity and elegance reign in this five-star ‘suites only' luxury concept destination, set in a vast tropical jungle. The cultural heritage of the island is reflected in its architecture's colonial accents. At nightfall, terraces bathed in golden light are veritable outdoor salons. When it comes to questions of wellness, Dinarobin has more than one trick up its sleeve: on the beach, two massage rooms have been adapted for a treatment augmented by warm sea breezes.

In the evening, the mystical atmosphere of its Spa by Clarins and Ayurvedic space is a sybaritic indulgence.

content.title: The Pescatore: a mandatory stopover

introduction.small: On Trou aux Biches beach in the north, a Mauritian restaurant has earned an international reputation. At Pescatore, fresh sea food and local produce are served with taste, originality, and passion.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Pescatore: a mandatory stopover

paragraphs.text:
From the beach, you can just make out a colonial style terrace in front of the large white open shutters. Lunch amidst the blue of the Indian Ocean is a promising prospect.

Looking up between bites, you might cast a glance around, just for a moment, so as to assure yourself that paradise is still there. The delights of the menu include yellowfin tuna with melon, ginger and mustard, seabream with mild pepper, or grilled calamari with a quinoa risotto and parmesan.

For dessert, a roasted Victoria pineapple with lassi ice cream will give you a fresh lasting note.

The Pescatore
Coastal Road
Trou aux Biches

+230 269 0333

www.pescatore.restaurant.mu

Menu: arounds 2,450 MUR

content.title: Fishing in Mahébourg Bay

introduction.small: Dotted with protected islands and islets, Mahébourg Bay is one of the most beautiful of Mauritius. In addition to its exceptional seabed, it is an ideal spot for fishing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fishing in Mahébourg Bay

paragraphs.text:
Small Mauritian fishing boats offer sport fishing, as Mahébourg Bay is full of very large fish lurking just offshore. Among generally sighted species: garfishes, damselfishes, scissortail sergeants and many more. But be warned: patience and physical strength are needed to land a blue marlin, a shark, a bonito, a pilgrim, or a barracuda.

For the less hardy, hand line fishing is also practiced a great deal on the island. On their small colourful boats, Mauritian fishermen will be happy to share their tricks with you. And to mix things up a bit, they regularly move anchor. What better way to explore the captivating turquoise waters of the Mahébourg Bay?

content.title: Plantation d'Albion Club Med: calm and tranquillity

introduction.small: The 5-Trident village ‘par excellence' in a magical and enchanting setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Plantation d'Albion Club Med: calm and tranquillity

paragraphs.text:
Nestled in one of the last wild coves of the island, La Plantation d'Albion offers tranquillity and serenity in a comfortable, relaxing wilderness setting, designed for the wellbeing of its guests. A rich profusion of exceptional vegetation, including tamarinds, cacti, royal poinciana (flamboyant trees), and banyan trees in the heart of a luxuriant green space provide the natural backdrop, while the sophisticated and upscale decor of the hotel's 266 rooms and suites with terraces or balconies open on to the vastness of the ocean or lush and lavish flowering gardens.

The two- and four-bedroom villas are also located in the heart of a tropical paradise, with decoration typical of the island. Take advantage of the wonderful Spa Cinq Mondes and the sublime, sparkling blue infinity pool. You can also practice various sports in the village, such as flying trapeze, golf, sailing, tennis, and diving. On the side of gastronomy, creative and refined cuisine is proposed in the various restaurants of the village.

Note also that La Plantation d'Albion Club Med has obtained the Green Globe certification for Sustainable Tourism.

La Plantation d'Albion Club Med
Avenue Du Club Med Albion
Albion
Mauritius

content.title: A princely residence

introduction.small: Le Prince Maurice is a sanctuary of luxury, emphasising elegance and privacy. And like an haute-couture dress, it is made to measure.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A princely residence

paragraphs.text:
The bluish light of dawn is reflected on your huge bay window. Drawn outside by the rich tropical greenery, your skin awakens to the cool morning breeze.

The water of the river at your feet immediately tempts you for a swim. Here, luxury is natural and the architecture tropical. Between each small house on stilts, the lush vegetation recalls the authenticity of the island. After a dip in the turquoise lagoon, it is already time to dress smartly for dinner.

Like small sand islands, the chic pontoons of the Archipelago await you. Savour the simple pleasures of nature and a generous cellar with the delicious sound of lapping water, while facing the rosy clouds in the receding light of sunset.

Prince Maurice Hôtel
Choisy Road

content.title: Sea Picnic on Rodrigues beach

introduction.small: Enjoy a delicious picnic by the sea, in the shade of a makeshift hut, on the soft white sand of a deserted beach on Rodrigues.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sea Picnic on Rodrigues beach

paragraphs.text:
Tonio is getting ready in his small shack full of island tastes and flavours. His art is based on the delicious simplicity of fresh island products. Find yourself a spot facing the lagoon and Tonio does the rest.

On the menu are the simple pleasures of life in the sun with dishes like lobster and grilled fish. The white flesh, tender and fresh and barely spiced, has cooked slowly on Tonio's grill, and it melts in your mouth.

The atmosphere is warm and open to sharing and when the picnic is over, alone in the world, you can take a postprandial stroll with your feet in the clear azure water of the Rodrigues' shoreline.

Da Tonio
Gravel beach
Mauritius

content.title: A historic dinner at Labourdonnais Castle

introduction.small: Immerse yourself in the lifestyle of the 19th century with dinner in the setting of this huge colonial mansion, dating back over 150 years.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A historic dinner at Labourdonnais Castle

paragraphs.text:
Everything here exudes colonial history. The house is imposing on two floors, and somewhat evocative of Gone with the Wind. Imagine a hot summer afternoon, overlooking the tall columns of the large balcony surrounding the house, the view of the blue horizon, tasting a papaya from the adjoining orchard, fan in hand. A light breeze (almost) brings you back to reality…

In the restaurant kitchens, the chef takes stock of his harvest of the day directly from the domain gardens. On the menu, Mauritian rougail and braised lamb, slowly cooked for seven hours. The vegetables of the day are sautéed in a wok, along with udon noodles and the fresh catch of the morning.

A delicious culinary interlude in the picturesque setting of the Mauritius of yesteryear.

Domaine de Labourdonnais
Mapou
Mauritius

+230 266 7172

www.tableduchateau.com

Menu: around 1,800 MUR

content.title: The cuisine of La Clef des Champs: from the heart

introduction.small: Here, there is a passion for ‘French cuisine that speaks Creole'. Generous portions are part of the delectable welcome you will receive.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The cuisine of La Clef des Champs: from the heart

paragraphs.text:
Jacqueline Dalais' passion for cooking is in her blood and comes from her bon vivant grandfather, and her parents, innkeepers on Touessrok Island when Mauritian tourism was still in its infancy. Within the tapestry of Mauritian diversity, La Clef des Champs is a strong testimony to the cultural mosaic.

Here, the excellence of French gastronomy is married with the richness of Mauritian produce. And the result is more than appetising, with family recipes for Thai sea food broth, octopus carpaccio, curry of scallops…

content.title: Swiss Family Robinson for a day on Deer Island

introduction.small: The pristine white beaches merging with the gradient of the clear turquoise water almost hurt the eyes. Welcome to Deer Island, one of Mauritius' most popular destinations.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Swiss Family Robinson for a day on Deer Island

paragraphs.text:
The sun's reflections off the white sand beaches make it seem as though you're lounging on a bed of diamonds. Following a swim in the blue lagoon, which offers some of the best snorkelling anywhere, adventure calls. Behind the palm trees, dense and abundant vegetation invites exploration, as mangroves and refreshing waterfalls punctuate the landscape of this paradise.

Such adventure opens the appetite and that's good, as the island offers two popular restaurants. The Masala specialises in Indian dishes, while Paul and Virginia feature fresh seafood. For an exotic dessert, head out to sea to discover the idyllic landscapes of Mangénie Island.

content.title: A mini-safari in Casela Nature Park

introduction.small: Here, nature has reclaimed its rights. The 14-hectare Casela Nature Park offers a glimpse of the abundant natural diversity of Mauritius: lush fauna, flora, and animals in their natural habitat.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A mini-safari in Casela Nature Park

paragraphs.text:
To venture into Casela is to discover Mauritius at its most natural. It means accepting all that the island offers—an exceptional natural world—which it does with conviction and authenticity.

For the athletic, hiking will prove an amazing experience as you see a lion lounging in the distance, a zebra grazing, an ostrich parading, while, without warning, a cheetah launches into a sprint. On one side, a macaque seems to be smiling at you. Slowly but surely, a giant turtle emerges from the water and, sitting on a branch, there is a pink pigeon, a rare and exotic species of the island.

For children, nothing could be more magical, except perhaps the mini-farm, where rabbits, peacocks, guinea pigs, and calves may be petted and befriended.

Casela World of Adventures

content.title: A party at the Heritage C Beach Club

introduction.small: If you are looking for a glamorous, festive evening with friends, the C Beach Club is where to go.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A party at the Heritage C Beach Club

paragraphs.text:
At the Heritage C Beach Club, the night is full of promise.

Start off relaxed with a cocktail on one of the four-poster beds installed on the beach, facing the blue horizon of the lagoon. Then head to the elegant and relaxed Cyan restaurant, which offers fine international cuisine in a bluish atmosphere. After dinner, things get serious at the Chill lounge bar. This trendy spot on the beach comes alive at sunset in a vibrant, festive atmosphere. Get up on the dance floor and shake a leg! Build up your strength, for it is quite sure that soft music will keep you up till the first light of day.

Heritage C Beach Club

content.title: Lunch on a bench at Tante Athalie

introduction.small: The authentic joys of simplicity define the dining experience in this former vintage car shed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lunch on a bench at Tante Athalie

paragraphs.text:
The story is beautiful. Alongside the traditional wooden house of Mon Repos stands a vintage car shed. This is where we honour the cuisine of the domain's aunt, whose recipes were found in an old book.

The quaint atmosphere is emphasised by wooden benches, and black-and-white photographs of Mauritius. A waitress with an infectious smile serves traditional dishes whose scents will enthral you: crab tartar, calamari flower fondant, and lamb shoulder with thyme sauce, fish curry, chicken in cumin, always served with rice, “grains” (red beans, lentils…) and achar, a hot pepper paste.

content.title: Discover Rodrigues Island

introduction.small: Lost in the middle of the Indian Ocean, a 90-minute flight from Mauritius, Rodrigues is the smallest of the Mascarene Islands. Authentic and secret, it's a little corner of paradise.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover Rodrigues Island

paragraphs.text:
Rodrigues, with its small hotel units and huge natural areas, which are due to the reduced amount of construction, is like Mauritius was 40 years ago.

Its blue lagoon, its sandy coves, and unspoilt nature offer an ideal vacation spot that is quiet and dressed in the colours of summer. Here, the always-smiling inhabitants have preserved their traditions and share the good life that animates them.

Rodrigues Island is a bit like a sepia-toned postcard of Mauritius, with its idyllic landscapes, borrowing the nostalgia of a recovered past.

content.title: Your compass indicates 20° South

introduction.small: At 20° South, every detail is the fruit of deep reflection. A constant search for perfection makes this small boutique hotel a unique resort of ineffable colonial charm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Your compass indicates 20° South

paragraphs.text:
Standing at the end of a stone alley lined with small palm trees, a heavy, solid-oak carriage entrance welcomes you.

Inside the building, the atmosphere that emanates from the sleek-but-warm decor is refined, like its hosts, a couple of Belgian expatriates.

A heavy wooden chess set poised for play rests on a table and, in the corner, a library filled with old books is there to be explored. Outside, a white hammock is strung between two palm trees where one might lounge at dusk. The bronze colours of the setting sun are enough to convince you: 20° South is definitely the perfect latitude for a privileged Mauritian getaway.

content.title: November in Triolet for the Hindu festival of Diwali

introduction.small: Mauritius offers astonishing cultural richness with its ethnic melting pot. Strolling in the village of Triolet during Diwali celebrations is a charming way to be reminded of this.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: November in Triolet for the Hindu festival of Diwali

paragraphs.text:
In the beautifully named Pamplemousses (grapefruits) region in the northwest of Mauritius stands Triolet, an authentic Creole city surrounded by greenery and idyllic landscapes. At the heart of this picturesque village is the Hindu temple Maheswarnath, the largest of the island.

Take off your shoes and remove any leather objects to explore this place of worship and to appreciate its joyful, colourful architecture. At night, it's not just the stars that sparkle: every year in November, Diwali (the ‘festival of lights') is in full swing. Houses and streets are adorned with decorations, and food abounds.

Triolet
Mauritius

content.title: Dive into Mauritian history at the Sugar Adventure

introduction.small: As pristinely white as the sand of its beaches, sugar has truly built the cultural identity of Mauritius. Discover its history at L'Aventure du Sucre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dive into Mauritian history at the Sugar Adventure

paragraphs.text:
Surrounded by bougainvillea and coconut trees at the end of a cane hedge, this former sugar refinery is a candy box of memories. The scents of fruit trees flatter the nostrils and mysterious rustling sounds invite you to enter, where you immediately discover the impressive old sugar-refining machinery.

Films, sound, and light, a floating barge and a locomotive whistle; here all of your senses as well as your imagination are called upon. L'Aventure du Sucre recounts 400 years of exciting, interactive history over 6,000 sqm.

A delicious, complex taste will be etched in your mind following the sugar and rum tastings.

L'Aventure du Sucre
Beau Plan – Pamplemousses
Mauritius

+230 243 7900

https://www.aventuredusucre.com/en

content.title: A morning at Port Louis' Central Market

introduction.small: Colours, scents, warmth, delights, taste buds, pleasures... Words are lost at the Port Louis Market as sensations explode, desires flourish, and all the senses are awakened.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A morning at Port Louis' Central Market

paragraphs.text:
It is advisable to visit the covered market of Port Louis early in the morning, before rush hour. Do not hesitate to get lost in its maze, protected from the sun, justifying its nickname of 'bazaar'. Turn right, turn left, go back. Take the time to understand the colours, to feel deep within you the atmosphere of this place, dating back over two centuries, and get lost in it.

Touch, smell, taste vegetables, or try a 'love apple' (a variety of tomato), spices like vanilla, Chinese noodles, cassava, pineapples... there are so many edible symbols of the island's cultural mix. In the takeaway corner (ready-to-eat), try a delicious dholl puri, a kind of pea pancake, and for a bit of sweetness, an alouda, a refreshing Mauritian drink made with vanilla or strawberry.

Central Market

content.title: Drift off course to Mangénie Island, and discover Restaurant Crusoe

introduction.small: When Mauritius seems too crowded, Mangénie Island, sister of Deer Island, has the desired tranquillity. Its castaway Restaurant Crusoe welcomes tourists, who are decidedly more epicurean than Robinson ever was!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Drift off course to Mangénie Island, and discover Restaurant Crusoe

paragraphs.text:
From Deer Island, you take a small sandy channel to get to Mangénie Island, which offers a beach of pure white sand and translucent turquoise water. Suddenly, the breeze brings you delicious scents.

At the Crusoe, the 'Robinsons' are busy in the kitchen. Here, simplicity is king as you seat yourself at wooden tables of contagious friendliness, just metres from the salt water.

The Mauritian dishes have pretty motifs and are laden with fresh lobster and grilled fish. For dessert, banana flambé, crepes, and coconut ice cream top off your meal.

content.title: Back to the past at Bakwa Lodge on Rodrigues Island

introduction.small: Rodrigues Island has a beating heart, alive with immense natural areas and discreet hotels. Among them, Bakwa Lodge assures an intimate stay in the wild.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Back to the past at Bakwa Lodge on Rodrigues Island

paragraphs.text:
With only eight bungalows and a villa, there is never a crowd at Bakwa Lodge.

Pastel colours, refined decoration, and driftwood intermingle, initiating a serene atmosphere where contemporary sophistication is enhanced, in all its simplicity, with traditional style. A little further down is the access to the almost-deserted beach, which sees few people other than the passage of a few fishermen from time to time.

Strolling along the lagoon with its turquoise sparkle will make you think you're in a dream, while the wilderness of the island offers the strange feeling of living outside of time

content.title: Tasting at the Chamarel rum distillery

introduction.small: A visit to the Chamarel distillery is a complete tourist experience, with its panorama of eco-conscious rums and fine restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tasting at the Chamarel rum distillery

paragraphs.text:
On the Chamarel plain, protected from the wind, the microclimate is perfect for delivering timely rains for growing cane.

On your way to the rum distillery, you'll come across pineapple fields, tropical fruits, and sugarcane, where harvesting is still done by hand. Once you've arrived, the elegant authenticity of the distillery invites discovery.

The rum here is produced from the domain's own sugarcane plantation, which functions eco-consciously to produce rums of high quality. You can taste about a dozen different rums, from several years old XOs to premiums and flavoured rums, which go a long way to immersing yourself in the history of colonial tastes. The domain also has a restaurant that features its own produce, sourced from the estate itself.

content.title: Otentic Creole lunch

introduction.small: In the heart of nature's riches, the Otentic offers a Creole lunch that will forever change your outlook on the island.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Otentic Creole lunch

paragraphs.text:
Everything in this restaurant overlooking the river is about sharing and conviviality. Your senses are constantly solicited by the richness of surrounding nature. In this magical setting, the restaurant seats about 50 patrons, amidst tents and wooden cabins. Smell a spice, touch a plant, and inhale the odours.

Discover the combinations, associations, and mixtures that make up the richness of Creole cuisine. Share ideas and question the village women who have prepared these specialties for you, and most importantly, explore by tasting!

content.title: Along the tea route

introduction.small: From Aubineaux to Saint-Aubin, the tea route stands out as a great traditional breakaway for discovering Mauritius' colonial past.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Along the tea route

paragraphs.text:
Destination: the Domaine des Aubineaux, one of the last colonial houses typical of the late 19th century.

Smelling the distinctive aromas of the antique wooden furniture – mostly dating from the East India Company – while discovering the old photographs is already quite a trip. The charming garden of camphor trees that surround the building is a haven of tranquillity. But already Bois Chéri, the second stage of the journey, arouses curiosity. After a tour of the tea factory, where you will be infused with the knowledge of its manufacturing secrets, take time to enjoy a cup, and offer yourself a contemplative break on the terrace of the chalet with its panoramic view over the south of the island.

In Saint-Aubin, the last leg of your journey, there will still be much to discover: a colonial house from 1819, a sugar factory, and a distillery.

content.title: Eureka House: a colonial odyssey

introduction.small:
Majestic, elegant, and historic, Eureka House offers a fascinating odyssey through time. Built in 1830, it is a window on to the compelling atmosphere of colonial life.
 ^p

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Eureka House: a colonial odyssey

paragraphs.text:
You are hardly in the lobby before history catches up with you, in a scene loaded with antiques and period photos. Politics might well be the topic of discussion here, while out on the long, shaded veranda that surrounds the house, a cup of tea seems ideal. But behind solid wooden doors there's another world that awaits you, dedicated to music and art.

In one corner, an old geographical map inspires ideas of evasion. This is because there is much to discover outside as well, with kilometres of hiking trails to explore, small waterfalls, indigenous plants and lush vegetation that compete for your attention in this magical land.

A change of scenery that might make the 21st century seem a bit lacklustre…

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Mauritius
content.introduction: Mauritius has a typically tropical climate and enjoys warm temperatures year-round. Summer, which extends from November to April, is hot and wet, whereas winter (from May to October) is warm and dry, with temperatures from June to August cooled by the trade winds.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in is the Mauritian Rupee (MUR).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam International Airport
airports.description:
The Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam International Airport is located about 48 kilometres (30 miles) south-east of the capital Port Louis.
  • One terminal

Getting from the airport to Port Louis and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the A10 (Royal Road).
    • A free drop-off and pick-up zone is located in front of the terminal. There are a total of 1,000 parking spaces in proximity to the terminal for both short- and long-term parking (MUR 30 for up to 1 hour, MUR 180 for 24 hours, MUR 90 for each additional day).
    • Several car rental companies have counters at the car rental facility just outside the Tour Operators hall.
  • By bus
    • Bus 198 connects the airport with Victoria Square Bus Station in Port Louis about every 10 minutes. The trip takes about 15 minutes and the fare is MUR 20 to 30.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks outside the terminal and the trip to Port Louis costs around MUR 1,500.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +230 203 9054
  • Website: https://mauritius-airport.atol.aero/

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Mauritius
transportation.description: Owing to its small size and the fact that most of its roads are in good condition, Mauritius is not at all difficult to explore by car. In addition, public transport on the island is efficient and reliable, making it relatively easy and quick to get from place to place.

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. It is recommended that you obtain insurance covering health care expenses as well as medical evacuation or repatriation before you leave home. Mauritius counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists. In case of medical treatment, it is also recommended to carry your own medicine, as importation regulations may render them hard to access.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
Visitors arriving from countries where there is a risk of yellow fever transmission must show proof of vaccination, usually documented on an International Certificate of Vaccination or Prophylaxis (ICVP).

In addition, the following vaccines are recommended for all visitors:

  • typhoid
  • hepatitis A and B
  • booster doses for protection against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis and polio

For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris

  • Phone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description: It is recommended to maintain good hygiene regarding food treatment (making sure food is cooked, and produce is carefully washed before eating).

information.title: Water
information.description: In Mauritius, tap water is safe to drink in hotels, but it is best to drink bottled mineral water.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Mauritius
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Mauritius each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January or February: Spring Festival (Chinese New Year, national holiday)
events.description: The Chinese New Year is celebrated on the island by Sino-Mauritians. For two days, the island's main municipalities, and Port Louis in particular, usher in the year with great panache. Highlights include Chinese dragons, lion dancers, and special events in front of shops, where firecrackers are lit to chase away evil spirits.

events.title: Early February: Thaipoosam Cavadee (national holiday)
events.description: Tamils in Mauritius celebrate this 10-day festival, in honour of the God Muruga. The faithful take part in colourful, spectacular and awe-inspiring processions to their temple. In addition, the participants undergo further penance, with skewers threaded through their tongues and cheeks.

events.title: March 12: National Day (national holiday)
events.description: All Mauritians celebrate the anniversary of the island's independence, proclaimed on this day in 1968. Commemorative events include speeches, a parade by security and paramilitary forces, a fireworks display as well as music and dance performances.

events.title: September 18: Ganesh Chaturthi (national holiday)
events.description: Hindu celebration in tribute to the Elephant god. During several days, Mauritians of Hindu origins praise this emblematic figure of Hindu faith. On this occasion, most families form processions, carrying statues of Ganesh to the ocean shores.

events.title: November 1: All Saints' Day (national)
events.description: On this day, Roman Catholic families in Mauritius visit the graves of their loved ones, to clean the tombs and place flowers. They also light candles, pray together, and share fond memories of the departed.

events.title: Early December: Festival International Kreol (local event)
events.description: With events held at a number of venues across the island, this annual 10-day celebration of Creole culture features exhibitions, conferences, food and craft stalls, traditional music and dance performances, among other highlights.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Mauritius
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need a visa to travel to Mauritius. Upon your arrival, a visa stamp is placed in your passport by an immigration inspector. However, your passport must be valid beyond the period of your stay.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Mauritius, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the Mauritius page of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs' website: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/mauritius/

banks.title: Banks

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime: No daylight savings time in Mauritius.
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Mauritius, tipping is not necessarily required, although always appreciated if you are satisfied with the service. It is customary to tip 10% of the bill in restaurants, bars and cafés.
